issues.title: Resource Exhaustion / Denial of Service
issues.author: dhs-aws
issues.body:
Creating this issue based on comments provided during the call for adoption:

How does the proposed specification address resource exhaustion or denial of service when multiple cursors are maintained over a period of time?

comments.author: dhs-aws
comments.body:
I suggest adding additional content to Section 5 that reads similar to the following:

`Service Provider implementors MAY consider not implementing cursor-based pagination in light of these security considerations.
`

comments.author: aaronpk
comments.body: This might be better explained in a few sentences in the introduction, to provide more context for when this extension applies in the first place.

comments.author: dhs-aws
comments.body: Thanks Aaron.  As discussed on today's call we'll aim to get the changes into a draft ahead of the IETF116 deadline.

comments.author: dhs-aws
comments.body: I believe this issue can now be closed.

issues.title: Resource locking
issues.author: dhs-aws
issues.body:
This issue was raised originally during the call for adoption.

How does the specification address locking resources when a resource is part of an active cursor?  Does this prevent updates to the underlying resources?

comments.author: dhs-aws
comments.body:
The question is, in essence, “if I have an active cursor and update the Nth record in the cursor, does the record update? And does the cursor update?”  I think we need two separate answers.  First, we should consider adding guidance such as:
 
`Implementors MUST NOT prevent resources from being updated (locking resources) while implementing cursor pagination.`
 
However, this change may lead to a lack of clarity about the state of the data in the cursor.  One way to address this is to enable options to support a point in time cursor vs. strongly consistent read where updates are included.  For example:
 
```
     GET /Users?filter=username%20sw%20J&cursor&count=10&consistentRead
     Host: example.com
     Accept: application/scim+json
     Authorization: Bearer U8YJcYYRMjbGeepD
 
     GET /Users?filter=username%20sw%20J&cursor&count=10&pointInTimeRead
     Host: example.com
     Accept: application/scim+json
     Authorization: Bearer U8YJcYYRMjbGeepD
```

Similar changes will need to be enabled for `POST` requests for consistency.  Note that there is no implementation guidance.  How an implementation achieves this is up to the implementer if they choose to implement cursor based pagination.
 
If we go this route, we'll also need to include some additional fields in the service provider configuration.  A first pass at defining these fields is below:
 
```
      cursorType A complex type that indicates support for cursor read strategies.  If cursor-based
      paginations are enabled this value is REQUIRED and at least one subvalue MUST be true.
 
         consistentRead A Boolean type indicating support for strongly consistent reads. 
         The client will always be returned the freshest data. OPTIONAL.
 
         pointInTimeRead A Boolean type indicating support for cursors returning data as it existed at
         the time of query execution. Changes to the dataset are not reflected in the cursor. OPTIONAL.
 
```

comments.author: dhs-aws
comments.body:
Today's WG meeting discussed this issue at length.  The only item we came to a general consensus on is that locking resources when a cursor is open is undesirable and a potential security flaw.  

We did not come to any conclusions on whether cursors are point in time or strongly consistent reads.  Please add your use cases to #3 in order to help identify which of these patterns is the desired end state.

comments.author: jaudriga
comments.body:
I agree with what was said during yesterday's WG meeting that defining two options might not be desirable for interoperability reasons.

As far as I can see one important use case for cusor-based pagination is paging through large amounts of data. In recent discussions one important aspect was that caching large amounts of data may lead to high resource consumption and potentially DoS. For point in time read, it is my understanding that the whole data set would need to be cached. For the other option keeping references to the result set should suffice. This is probably an important disadvantage of point in time, when the goal is paging through a really large data set.

On another note it seems that not all systems support strongly consistent read. E.g. [Amazon DynamoDB](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/amazondynamodb/latest/developerguide/HowItWorks.ReadConsistency.html) does not support it in all circumstances.

Instead of having two options here it might make sense to state that the result set will contain "eventually consistent" data? This would not impose additional requirements on SCIM server implementations. Of course clients would then need to cope with the situation that results will be partially up to date regarding the point in time when they opened up their cursor. As far as I can see will then affect how clients handle future delta queries.

comments.author: ansg-aws
comments.body:
Below is the what we can add to the document.

*********
Implementors MUST NOT prevent resources from being updated (locking resources) while implementing cursor pagination. New objects can be added or existing objects can be removed or updated. 

Result sets MUST implement eventually consistent data. Result sets MAY implement strongly consistent datasets.

The cursor based pagination gaurantees that records are not skipped nor appear as duplicates. New records MAY be appended to the cursor. Deletions MAY be absent from the returned record set if a page is retrieved after the deletion has occurred.
***********************

comments.author: dhs-aws
comments.body: Given the progress on the draft and WGLC, I will close this issue.

issues.title: Cursor Based Pagination Use Cases
issues.author: dhs-aws
issues.body: What are your use cases for cursor based pagination?  In order to resolve the discussion on #2 we'd like to work backwards from the implementation use cases to ensure the proposed changes accurately reflect the needs of implementors.  Please add your use cases here.

comments.author: ansg-aws
comments.body: The SCIM Cursor based pagination applies to the same use cases as index based pagination does. It's an alternative to index based pagination. Line#86 through 93 provides the need for cursor based pagination as an alternative. For Issue#2 we have provided a verbiage on the issue. We will update the next draft with the new language. Hence, the use cases for the pagination as generic requirement should be covered under the SCIM Use Cases document.

comments.author: pamelatech
comments.body:
Here is a use case that maybe we can react to and then tune/reject:  
Scenario:  a SCIM server offers a total set of 5 million user objects and a SCIM client wants to keep those objects synchronized in their own systems.   The SCIM client requests a paginated list of all 5 million objects, and are served 1000 objects at a time.  This means that 5000 separate fetches will be required for the SCIM client to completely synchronize their data set.  Due to performance/throttling reasons, it take 5 hours for all 5000 fetches to complete.  During that 5 hours, objects in the sorting order in which the data is served change:   object 1 is deleted after 10 minutes, object 5 is deleted after 4 hours, object 4500 is deleted after 15 minutes.  a new object is created that would be #4800 for a new query 3 hours after the initial paginated response is created.  Object #300 changes one hour in, and object 2500 changes two hours in.  What does the dataset look like for an index-paginated result set, a strongly consistent result set and an eventually consistent result set?    Assuming I've picked the right times and object numbers, I think we should be able to see the differences in what state the client will be in at the end of processing the entire result set.  None of the result sets at the client will exactly mirror the state at the scim server, but hopefully there is a simple way to summarize what developers can know they have at the end.  Let me know if that kind of approach makes sense.

issues.title: Cursor lifetime
issues.author: andrewclymer
issues.body: I've read the paging cursor, specification. How long can a client guarantee they can use the nextCursor value?

comments.author: ansg-aws
comments.body: Thank you Andrew for the question. It depends on the Server Implementor. The Server Provider Configuration exposes the "cursorTimeout" parameter to guarantee that clients can use the nextCursor value for the duration of Timeout period.

comments.author: andrewclymer
comments.body: Thanks, can't believe  I missed it

pulls.title: Updates for nits v04
pulls.author: ansg-aws
pulls.body:
In the Abstract and Introduction, a nit:
“is already well established” should not be hyphenated, as it’s not a modifier
(whereas “a well-established pagination pattern” is correctly hyphenated).
**Resolution**: removed hyphen

— Section 2 —

The following table describes the URL pagination parameters requests
for using cursor-based pagination:

I think the word “requests” is extra and should be removed (or perhaps “using”
should be replaced by “requesting”).

**Resolution**: replaced "requests for using" with "for requesting"

In the second table you say “Use of previousCursor is OPTIONAL.” That seems to
say that using it in a subsequent request is optional, which is already said in
the previous sentence. I think this one should say, “Returning previousCursor
is OPTIONAL.”

**Resolution**: replaced “Use of previousCursor is OPTIONAL.” with "Returning previousCursor
is OPTIONAL."
b933bfd

pulls.title: Add backwards compatibility considerations
pulls.author: planux
pulls.body: In response to feedback, adding section describing backwards compatibility in cases where the SCIM Service Provider is contemplating switching the default pagination method on return sets to the cursor-based method.

pulls.title: Updates-for-nancy's-feedback
pulls.author: ansg-aws
pulls.body:
* I do not see any of the “should” as “SHOULD” though in some of the reading  Perhaps there are instances in which they are perhaps requirements and should be capitalized. Done
Simli
* Section 2.4 “…method as-is will not impact”,  this statement implies that     any implementation that adds cursor-based pagination support not impact    existing clients but that is based on implementation, my recommendation     is to make the “will” to a “should”.
Done
 
* Section 5: it would be good to mention that this draft is under the same Security and privacy considerations of those described in RFC 7644. Done

Editorial Nits
* Section 2.1 “…other error condition” should read “….other error conditions” Done

comments.body: Restructure sentence to add normative requirement? Wording here feels weird..
